content:
Hi, I have a conjunction A ∧ B ∧ C, and I want to do something like repeat apply And.intro to split it into individual cases, but due to associativity this only splits into A and B ∧ C and then stops. Is the right way to do this by applying associativity transformations first to turn it into (A ∧ B) ∧ C, or is there a way to do something like repeat { apply And.intro; SWITCH_GOALS } to put the second goal as the first?

Minimal example:

example (a b c d : Prop) : a ∧ b ∧ c ∧ d := by
    repeat apply And.intro
If you're using mathlib, take a look at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/Underscores.20in.20cases.20tactics/near/472994479
Vlad Tsyrklevich has marked this topic as resolved.

Thanks! repeat' is not documented at https://leanprover.github.io/reference/tactics.html Is there a more definitive list of tactics I can reference in the future, or is this just one of those things you have to know at the moment?
You can also say refine ⟨?_, ?_, ?_⟩ which is a shortcut to refine ⟨?_, ⟨?_, ?_⟩⟩ (but that only works if the number of subterms is known and small).
